description.narrative:
In Uganda, this Reconstruction programme will focus on the following outcomes:
Outcome 1: Increased trust and cooperation among and within the various groups
Outcome 2: Reduction in conflict over land and water
Outcome 3: Increased utilization of alternative livelihood resources and formal & non-formal education systems

Intended number of direct and indirect beneficiaries of the three sub-counties Amudat, Karita and Loroo6:
- 24,000 with sensitization on rule of law, - 25,000 with watershed reconstruction, crop production and training, - Minimum 900 people for FAL.

The proposed programme will contribute to the improvement of human security by reducing conflict over land and water, through a comprehensive and appropriate package of interventions in three areas facing similar issues. These areas are selected districts of Saripul and Jawzjan Provinces in northern Afghanistan; Dar El Salaam and Kalamendo localities in North Darfur, Sudan; and Amudat District in the Karamoja region of north-eastern Uganda.

activity-date.narrative: The project received initial approval from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on 28th June 2012 for a total amount of 60% of the proposed budget at the time of submission in March 2012. ZOA was then asked to submit a revised project plan by latest 15th September 2012. The Ministry notified ZOA of the approval of the revised plan on 16th November 2012, after which ZOA started implementation of the project. ZOA found it best to not start the revised project immediately after submission in September 2012 so not to run the risk of beginning project work on a wrong footing, we considered the operational risks of starting the project without having received the donor’s ultimate directions, too high. Therefore, we could only start full project preparations in second half of November.

policy-marker.narrative: The main objective is to contribute to the improvement of human security by reducing conflict over land and water, through a comprehensive and appropriate package of interventions

description.narrative: Access to water is increased
By the end of the project, dry season drinking water availability for livestock has increased by 15% in at least 50% of the targeted communities where livestock is a major livelihoods strategy.

comment.narrative: N/A: To be done in intake survey.
15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in dry season drinking water availability for livestock in 50% of the targeted communities
8 communities were targeted and engaged in improvements of their ponds, both through catchment areas and improvement of silt traps/overflows and volume of water in the ponds by desilting
15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in dry season drinking water availability for livestock in 50% of the targeted communities

Improvement of catchment areas and silt traps/overflows increased the volume of water in the ponds by desilting. The general migration by the cattle keepers was delayed by at least 2 months i.e. from November to late January
15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in dry season drinking water availability for livestock in 50% of the targeted communities
The water resources map has been developed. Feasibilitiy studies for the potential water sources are conducted. Tools have been procured.
15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in dry season drinking water availability for livestock in 50% of the targeted communities
Water ponds with cumulative capacity of 26,700 cubic metres have been finalised. Measurement of impact shall be Q1 2016

description.narrative: Availability of formal education facilities and non-formal education has increased
By the end of the project, 30% of the targeted communities in Uganda and Sudan have access to an adequate primary education facility within 5 km walking distance

comment.narrative: N/A: No reliable statistics available yet, plus this is an end of project indicator
Accurate figure not established. The map indicating the relative access to schools in the target communities has been developed. Two communities have been supported to construct new primary schools.
Education facilities in 5 communities out of the targeted 16 communities (31%) constructed, within the 5km walking distance
No data available, will be measured in June 2016. 2 community schools have been completed; 3 other community schools under construction

No data available, will be measured in June 2016. 3 community schools were constructed by the project while 24 non formal education facilities (FAL) centres were established increased availability of such education facilities in the project communities.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 80% of the participants in FAL classes have basic reading, writing and numeracy skills

comment.narrative: N/A: To be done in intake survey, by mapping

175 (M106/F69) / 81% of the learners were able to read and write. FAL learners’ assessment was conducted in all the 3 sub counties in collaboration with District Community Development Services department.
18 centres were operational with 765 learners enrolled; 42.3% females 51.5% males
3 centres have been opened and 166 learners (99 male & 67 female) recruited. A pretest for the learners was conducted. Refer to narrative for details.
Although this indicator was not achieved, efforts by ZOA to improve the ability of respondents to read, write and calculate are largely appreciated compared to the midterm results.

description.narrative: Capacity for increased productivity of crops and/or livestock is improved
By the end of the project, the cropped area for the targeted households in Uganda has increased by 20%

comment.narrative: 0.28 ha available land per household
20% increase when compared to baseline
2 acres to 6.5 acres per household on average or 44%
20% increase when compared to baseline
No figure available
20% increase when compared to baseline
There was an increase of the area under cultivation from an average of 0.28 ha per household before the project to 0.88 ha per household at the end of the project.
20% increase when compared to baseline
To be measured in March 2014 at the onset of new season.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 60% of targeted households in Uganda apply improved animal husbandry skills

comment.narrative: N/A: Might be done in intake survey
92% of the targetted households gained at least 1 skill or more, 62.5% had acquired between 6 and 7 skills
N/A
The current skills and the gaps have been assessed. The training materials have been developed.

This increase in livestock productivity was attributable to improved management of animal diseases and pests (53.2%), animal health education e.g nutrition (45%), improved access to water sources (42%), and reduced conflicts for water and pasture (19%)

description.narrative: Capacity of local leadership and civil society to manage land and water resources in a sustainable, effective, equitable and conflict sensitive way is enhanced
At least 80% of agreed capacity strengthening measures with partner organisations have been implemented by the partner

comment.narrative: N/A: End of project indicator
5C assessment for the 2 implementing partners has been conducted. See narrative for the analysis of scores and areas of focus in capacity development.

5C assessments were followed and trainings planned accordingly. Capacity building has taken place. The 5C assessment does not provide information which measures have been implemented. This will be measured in June 2016.
All the capacity needs identified during 5C assessment were implemented by the partner.
Capacity building has taken place. The 5C assessment does not provide information which measures have been implemented. This will be measured in June 2016.

comment.narrative: N/A: End of project indicator

No figure needed: refer to chapter 4 of annual report
The skills they could demonstrate independently were more agronomic; like line spacing and inter cropping and less related to water resources and environmental management.
The skills they could demonstrate independently were more agronomic; like line spacing and inter cropping and less related to water resources and environmental management.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 60% of PTA/SMC members are able to give relevant examples of how they are involved in the monitoring of the school

comment.narrative: N/A: End of project indicator
No figure available, will be measured June 2016. Seven PTA/SMCs have been trained on their roles and responsibilities. Narrative has examples of how they have been involved in monitoring
Six PTA/SMCs have been oriented on their roles and responsibilities. 4 out of the 12 planned are involved in monitoring. See narrative for examples of how they have been involved in monitoring.
This was attributed to the high illiteracy levels among the SMCs/PTAs members combined with the limited motivation to take action.
This was lower than planned due to very high illiteracy levels among the SMCs/PTAs.

description.narrative: Groups are empowered to realize their rights and duties
By the end of the project, 50% of the people in the Ugandan target area can reproduce key information about legislation that is relevant for their specific lives and livelihoods

comment.narrative: 31.3% of population is able to reproduce at least content on 1 legislation. Most on health and education. Higher fraction is aware of legislation but can not reproduce. Detail of reproduction not assessed specifically.
Key legislations have been simplified and packaged in the language and context thats applicable to the situation in the project (Amudat).
Not measured during MTR, activities planned for 2015 & 2016
the number of targeted beneficiaries who were knowledgeable about these legislations rose from 5,040 at the baseline to 16,560 at the end of the project.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 40% of the people in the Ugandan target area can explain how they will use this knowledge for the benefit of their communities and themselves

comment.narrative: Indicator referring to perception of relevance by interviewees. Multiple answers for land, water, education and health summed up.

11,280 (47%) of the targeted beneficiaries were able to explain how they plan to use this knowledge for the benefit of their community and themselves, as compared to the targeted 9,600 beneficiaries (40%)
Not measured during MTR
Same as under indicator 1.3.1: Key legislations have been simplified and packaged in the language and context that\\\'s applicable to the situation in the project (Amudat).

These indicated that they will use the knowledge to create awareness and sensitize communities about the legislations and to advocate for their livelihood rights and those of the communities they live in.

description.narrative: Increased trust and cooperation among and within the various groups
By the end of the project, 40% of people in the targeted area in Uganda can give examples of increased local government accountability

comment.narrative: Measurement as at 31 dec 2014: could serve as baseline as the intervention is mainly planned in 2015 and 2016.
No data reported on outcome level yet
Result (14%) could serve as baseline, as the intervention is mainly planned in 2015 and 2016

The variance is attributable to the fact that the high illiteracy levels among the targeted beneficiaries limited understanding of accountability. Furthermore, community members seemed more focussed on receiving services on the ground rather than being interested in ensuring the quality of these services. Moreover, illiteracy and lack of education give the Pokot a lack of self-esteem and confidence to engage in certain accountability activities
Variance explained by Illiteracy, focus on basic services not on quality and lack of self-esteem

description.narrative: By the end of the project, the percentage of people that identify operational local conflict resolution mechanisms has increased by 30%

comment.narrative: During the end of the project evaluation this percentage was recorded at 98%, which indicated that the indicator is not measuring the right change and should have focused more on the functionality of these mechanisms. Mediation, arbitration and compensation are mainly used as peaceful ways to resolving their conflicts.
An increase of 30% when compared to the baseline
No data reported on outcome level yet
An increase of 30% when compared to the baseline
Will be measured at end of project - June 2016
baseline most respondents indicated operational conflict resolution mechanisms in place. 2015 this percentage of respondents was recorded at 98%,

description.narrative: By the end of the project, primary school attendance in target areas in Uganda and Sudan has increased by 25%

comment.narrative: Physical headcount in 1st term for 15 of the 23 schools indicated an attendance of 1.633 pupils
an increase of 25% when compared to the baseline (1.633)
By the end of 2014 an increase of 7% was observed, which is lower than the expected 12.5%
an increase of 25% when compared to the baseline (1.633)
No data reported on outcome level yet
an increase of 25% when compared to the baseline (1.633)

Still there were many fluctuations during the terms. Furthermore, headcount varied even within terms. Lastly, 3 out of the 5 community schools supported under buza have been measured in attendance. Other 2 will be included from 2016
an increase of 25% when compared to the baseline (1.633)

Still there were many fluctuations during the terms. Furthermore, headcount varied even within terms. The increase in enrolment is attributed to the tireless efforts by the SMCs/PTAs in putting extra emphasis on the importance of the trainings under the project.

description.narrative: No progress yet on outcome/output level as in description due to a revision of the project plan by latest 15th September 2012. The Ministry notified ZOA of the approval of the revised plan on 16th November 2012, after which ZOA started implementation of the project. Therefore below some general information on implementation per country: UGANDA: ZOA has implemented the project in Uganda during 2012 by carrying out essential preparations of recruitment of a project manager, sourcing for an external consultant for the baseline survey and 4WD vehicle procurement (collection of quotations).

title.narrative: Not applicable for this annual report: see narrative above

description.narrative: Reduction in conflict over land and water
By the end of the project, morbidity rates of targeted livestock types in the targeted area in Uganda have reduced by 5%

comment.narrative: Baseline: 65% cattle / 73% goats / 90% sheep Livestock disease prevalence is perceived as high by population. Officially verified disease records are much lower. We choose to use records of HH survey.
Decrease of 5% when compared to baseline
Comparison made between 2014 and 2015, based on estimates given during recent data collection.
Decrease of 5% when compared to baseline
No data reported on outcome level yet
Decrease of 5% when compared to baseline
No data, will be measured in June 2016: end of project indicator
Decrease of 5% when compared to baseline
This was attributed to improved management of animal diseases and pests and animal health education due to livestock trainings by the project. This eventually improved the productivity in livestock.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 50% of the targeted agricultural households have increased their annual cereal crop production by at least 10%

comment.narrative: N/A: To be done in intake survey by crop cards
An increase of 10% when compared to the baseline
A rise up to 803 kg/household of grain equivalent at the end of project, indicating 61% increase in yield
An increase of 10% when compared to the baseline
At intake farmers averagely produced 498kg, while 2015 averagely 803kg. Increase of 60% compared to baseline
An increase of 10% when compared to the baseline, but this has to be done in intake survey by crop cards
No data reported on outcome level yet
An increase of 10% when compared to the baseline, but this has to be done in intake survey by crop cards
The data collected using the crop card was distorted due to an early onset of the dry period that resulted in massive crop failure

description.narrative: By the end of the project, there is an increase of 20% in the peacefully resolved conflicts that people have experienced themselves

comment.narrative: Only conflicts over land and water have been measured.

Land conflicts are due to the growing interest in accessing and owning land for agriculture, yet there is complexity around solving land issues. Water conflicts were solved easily by the Water User Committees and Natural Resource Management Committees.
20% increase in comparison to the baseline above
No data reported on outcome level yet
20% increase in comparison to the baseline above
The percentage of water and land related conflicts that were peacefully resolved in 2014 was 77% which is 20% more than the baseline

This was attributed to trained water project management committees, who have the task to oversee that everybody has equitable access to water and assist in conflict resolution. Community Conflict Management Committees (CMCCs) have positively contributed to resolving existing conflicts and reducing tensions before conflicts develop.
